title: Angular Framework: 50+ Fresher Interview Questions & Answers (2026)
description: Start your enterprise frontend journey. 50+ essential questions covering Angular CLI, components, templates, data binding, and basic dependency injection.

sections.title: Introduction: Mastering the Enterprise Framework
sections.content: Angular is a complete platform for building scalable web applications. For freshers in 2026, the key is understanding **Components**, **Directives**, and the power of the **Angular CLI**. Unlike lightweight libraries, Angular provides everything out of the box. This guide covers 50+ fundamental questions to help you land your first role as an Angular developer.

sections.title: 1. Angular Fundamentals
sections.content:
**Q1: What is Angular?**
Angular is an open-source, TypeScript-based web application framework maintained by Google. It's used for building Single-Page Applications (SPAs) and providing a structured development environment.

**Q2: Angular vs. AngularJS.**
AngularJS (1.x) was JavaScript-based. Angular (2+) is a complete rewrite based on TypeScript and is component-based, more performant, and has better tooling.

**Q3: What is TypeScript?**
A superset of JavaScript developed by Microsoft. It adds static typing to JavaScript, making it easier to find errors during development and improving code maintainability.

**Q4: What is a Single Page Application (SPA)?**
A web application that interacts with the user by dynamically rewriting the current web page with new data from the web server, instead of loading entire new pages.

**Q5: What is the Angular CLI?**
A command-line interface tool used to initialize, develop, scaffold, and maintain Angular applications directly from a shell.

sections.title: 2. Components & Layout
sections.content:
**Q6: What is a Component?**
The basic building block of an Angular UI. Every component consists of a TypeScript class (logic), an HTML template (view), and a CSS/Sass file (style).

**Q7: The `@Component` decorator.**
A function that attaches metadata to a class. It tells Angular which template and styles to use and how to refer to the component in other templates via its `selector`.

**Q8: What is a Template?**
A form of HTML that tells Angular how to render the component. Templates use special syntax like `{{ }}` or `[ ]` to bind data from the class to the view.

**Q9: What is Selector?**
A CSS selector that identifies this component in a template. Example: `<app-root></app-root>` uses the selector `app-root`.

**Q10: Inline vs. External templates.**
You can write your HTML directly in the `.ts` file using the `template` property, or keep it in a separate `.html` file using `templateUrl`. External is preferred for complex views.

sections.title: 3. Data Binding Mastery
sections.content:
**Q11: What is Interpolation?**
Using double curly braces `{{ value }}` to display component data in the template. It flows data from the TypeScript class to the HTML view.

**Q12: What is Property Binding?**
Using square brackets `[property]="value"` to set the value of an HTML element's property. Example: `[src]="imagePath"`.

**Q13: What is Event Binding?**
Using parentheses `(event)="handler()"` to listen for user actions (like clicks). It flows data from the view back to the TypeScript class.

**Q14: What is Two-Way Data Binding?**
Using the `[(ngModel)]` syntax. Changes in the UI update the class property, and changes in the class property update the UI simultaneously.

**Q15: When to use `ngModel`?**
Mainly in forms to synchronize input values with component data. You must import `FormsModule` from `@angular/forms` to use it.

sections.title: 4. Directives: Logic in HTML
sections.content:
**Q16: What are Directives?**
Classes that add new behavior or modify the structure/style of elements in the DOM.

**Q17: Structural vs. Attribute Directives.**
Structural directives (`*ngIf`, `*ngFor`) change the DOM layout by adding/removing elements. Attribute directives (`ngClass`, `ngStyle`) change the appearance or behavior of an existing element.

**Q18: How does `*ngIf` work?**
It conditionally includes or removes an element from the DOM based on a boolean expression. Note the asterisk (`*`), which denotes a structural directive.

**Q19: How does `*ngFor` work?**
It iterates over a list of items and renders a template block for each item in the list.

**Q20: What is `ngSwitch`?**
Similar to a JavaScript switch statement. It chooses one element from multiple possible options to display based on a condition.

sections.title: 5. Component Communication
sections.content:
**Q21: How to pass data from Parent to Child?**
Using the `@Input()` decorator in the child component class and property binding in the parent template.

**Q22: How to pass data from Child to Parent?**
Using the `@Output()` decorator with an `EventEmitter` in the child component. The parent listens for the event in its template.

**Q23: What is an EventEmitter?**
A class used to emit custom events in Angular, typically used with the `@Output()` decorator.

**Q24: What is 'Content Projection'?**
Using the `<ng-content></ng-content>` tag to inject HTML or other components from a parent into a specific spot in a child component.

**Q25: What is Template Reference Variable?**
Using a hash symbol `#variableName` in HTML to get a reference to a DOM element or an Angular component/directive to use it elsewhere in the template.

sections.title: 6. Life Cycle Hooks
sections.content:
**Q26: What are Life Cycle Hooks?**
Special methods that Angular calls at specific moments during a component's life (creation, update, destruction).

**Q27: What is `ngOnInit`?**
The most common hook. It's called once after the component's properties have been initialized. Use it for initialization logic and data fetching.

**Q28: `constructor` vs. `ngOnInit`.**
The constructor is a standard TypeScript feature for class initialization. `ngOnInit` is an Angular hook that runs after Angular has finished setting up the component's inputs and properties.

**Q29: What is `ngOnDestroy`?**
Called just before Angular destroys the component. Use it for cleanup logic (like unsubscribing from observables or clearing timers).

**Q30: What is `ngOnChanges`?**
Called whenever one or more input properties (`@Input`) of the component change. It receives a `SimpleChanges` object.

sections.title: 7. Services & Dependency Injection
sections.content:
**Q31: What is a Service?**
A broad category encompassing any value, function, or feature that an application needs. Frequently used for data fetching and sharing logic across components.

**Q32: What is Dependency Injection (DI)?**
A design pattern where a class requests dependencies (like services) from external sources rather than creating them itself. Angular has a built-in DI system.

**Q33: How to create a Service?**
Using the Angular CLI: `ng generate service my-service`. This creates a class decorated with `@Injectable()`.

**Q34: What is `@Injectable()`?**
A decorator that marks a class as available to be provided and injected as a dependency.

**Q35: What is `providedIn: 'root'`?**
It tells Angular to provide the service at the root level, making it a singleton available throughout the entire application and allowing the compiler to 'tree-shake' it (remove it if unused).

sections.title: 8. Pipes & Data Transformation
sections.content:
**Q36: What are Pipes?**
Simple functions used in templates to transform data before displaying it (e.g., formatting dates, currency, or case).

**Q37: Common built-in pipes.**
`uppercase`, `lowercase`, `date`, `currency`, `percent`, `decimal`, and `json`.

**Q38: How to use a pipe?**
Using the pipe `|` character in an interpolation expression: `{{ birthday | date }}`.

**Q39: What is the Async Pipe?**
A powerful pipe that subscribes to an Observable or Promise and returns the latest value it has emitted. It also handles unsubscription automatically.

**Q40: Can you create custom pipes?**
Yes. You create a class decorated with `@Pipe()` and implement the `PipeTransform` interface's `transform()` method.

sections.title: 9. Basic Routing & Navigation
sections.content: **Q41: What is the Angular Router?** A library that enables navigation among different views or components in the application as the user interacts with it. **Q42: What is ``?** A directive that acts as a placeholder where the router renders the matched component for the current URL. **Q43: What is a Route?** An object that maps a URL path to a specific component. Example: `{ path: 'home', component: HomeComponent }`. **Q44: What is `routerLink`?** A directive used on anchor tags to navigate to different routes without a full page reload. Example: `Home`. **Q45: Wildcard Route.** A route with path `**` that matches any URL. It's often used to display a '404 - Not Found' page.

sections.title: 10. Environment & Tooling
sections.content:
**Q46: What is 'NgModule'?**
A class decorated with `@NgModule` that groups components, directives, pipes, and services into functional blocks. In modern Angular, 'Standalone Components' are often used instead.

**Q47: What are Standalone Components?**
Components that don't need to be part of an `NgModule`. They are the new standard for building Angular apps as of v14+.

**Q48: How to run an Angular app?**
By running `ng serve` in the terminal. This starts a development server and reloads the browser automatically when you make changes.

**Q49: What is 'Ahead-of-Time' (AOT) compilation?**
A process where Angular compiles your application components and templates into efficient JavaScript code *before* the browser downloads it.

**Q50: What is `angular.json`?**
The main configuration file for the Angular workspace. It defines build settings, asset paths, and project-specific options.

sections.title: Summary & Next Steps
sections.content: Awesome! You've successfully reviewed 50+ fundamental questions for an Angular Fresher role. Angular is a powerful framework with a great community. The next step is to build a small app with CRUD operations to solidfy your knowledge. Happy coding and good luck!
